title: How many federal firearm background checks will be initiated in the US from April 2021 through June 2021?
preds: Post-mortem: This was a good forecast. See previous rationales. Still not sure because even if the average rate of increase is inputted for June compared to May, it still does not reach 10M—but barely. But then again, it's an above-average year so perhaps the said base rate may not be quite as applicable. However, I graphed all the data I could find and found a cyclical trend that indicates to me that perhaps 10M may not be reached. For this update, I lean a tad bit into the crowd median compared to previous forecast.

Took a deep look at seasonality across Presidents' first years, election years, and other years. Across two of the buckets (first years and other years), June numbers are on average lower than May numbers. In fact, only 4 of the last 23 years have seen increases from May to June, and all of them (00, 04, 16, and 20) were election years.   One thing I'm not sure quite what to make of is the giant spike in June and July of 2020, which is probably partially driven by all the discussion of police violence - perhaps wild notions about some coming civil war drove a spike in sales. Not a sure thing at all, but I'm inclined to believe that these two months are outliers as they quite clearly not in line with the summer patterns in any previous year (2016 also had a spike, but not nearly as dramatic, and 00 and 04 were tiny bumps/essentially flat, and all other years decreased from May to June).  To be over 12M, June would have to be ~5.3M, which would be ~13% higher than any other month ever. This strikes me as extraordinarily unlikely, especially given the lack of any obvious driver of gun-buying behavior in the last month. I'm assigning it 1% because zeroes make me uncomfortable. We haven't seen a month under 1.3M since 2013 I think, and the trend is clearly upward, so I'm going 0% on <8M. As for the two other buckets, I'll explore what I think are the most likely scenarios. If we use analogs of President first years, Obama 09 only, or Obama 09 and 12 to forecast June from January, February, March, April, and May data, we get a range of 2.5-3.8M with a mean of 3.15M and a median of 3.29M. Just looking at the May-June historical seasonality (including Presidential first years), I'd be inclined to give 8-10M a lot more weight than 10-12M (maybe as much as 80%+). I also get the sense based on the data that there was a rush to buy in the Nov-March time frame, but that bump appears to be returning closer to normal over the last two months. However, I do want to weigh in the mini-forecasts based on the data from the last few months combined with historical trends, which would put me close to even, but with a slight edge for 8-10M. Looking at all of that, I'm going to settle for 65% in the 8-10M bucket. I recognize this is very contrarian, so I figured I'd give a full explanation. Curious to see what others think of this, particularly any quants who have a better sense of how to refine my framework/mindset into final probability estimates.
Risk off. Also, when you start to feel that "everybody's lost but me [1] ," it is very rarely true.  cc: @Scappleby [1] https://getyarn.io/yarn-clip/d0ed92a9-7622-45b9-9c43-813edb2b0354

I did not stay on top of my updates as data came out this spring. right now the april and may numbers total 6,736,175. If it stays on trend it will be just barely above 10m, it is possible sales could decline enough to put it just below the 10m cutoff but very unlikely that they would increase enough to put it over 12m (would have to be the highest single month ever)
Evening out a stupid earlier forecast

The numbers seem pretty suggestive at this point.  Show me some love if you agree with the following:
Total of April and May is 6.736MM.
To come in under 10MM, June must be < 3.263. This is possible but certainly not on trend.  
To come in over 12MM, June must be > 5.263.  This would be 500K greater than any number we have seen.
So, for sure it's extremely likely the number will be between 3.263MM and 5.263MM.  A bit personal how much weight to put on the outlier situations occurring.  I could not find any news coverage suggesting how June number look.  If you find, please share!

at the link below - ignore the 2A rah rah and listen to the numbers, and he has all the links which is why I posted this.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SY5pcITtHc
Just look at the previous ones.

Is there something I'm missing here? April and May's numbers add up to 6,73M registrations this requires 5.24M new regos in June to hit 12M+, 550,000 more than the previous monthly high (or a sudden 11% bump on the previous record).  In my mind this makes 12M+ extremely unlikely.
With the passage of time and no headline event to spur numbers abnormally high I'm moving 6% from the 12-14 into the 8-10 as a hedge

Upping the 10m threshold to follow logic of crowd after shooting and potential legislation. Not that any ban will make a difference now with the number of guns floating around in the US.  There has been more than one background check per person cumulative now in the US.  Even taking into account time and that one person may get checked more than one and so on, that is just bonkers. With 3m checks per month that is 0.1pc of the population getting checks every month.  And I haven’t even deducted for underage, so the pc is actually higher.
Even though an uptick is likely, just can't bring myself to see enough checks in June (5,263,825) to hit 12,000,000.
Registrations have remained around 3MM/month, and there have been no big events to stimulate buying. Moved my estimate from just above 10 to just below.
Revised based on May numbers and recent shootings
With the mass shooting in Texas, 12 June 2021, it is possible that gun sales go up in response.
No big mass shooting that's individually gotten a lot of coverage, but more shootings in general. Putting more in the 10-12 bucket.

I decided to go all in as I expect the 26 May 2021 San Jose VTA shooting will tip the number of NCIS checks over the 10.0mn mark with the June numbers, for two reasons:
/increased fear-related sales (and background checks) in June in California
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/05/26/us/san-jose-shooting/index.html /increase of planned but advanced purchases nationwide due to Pres. Biden's call for "immediate action" on gun legislation in the wake of it
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/05/26/politics/biden-san-jose-shooting/index.html

Rethinking, based on the fact that Californian judges "Benitez ruled that the Golden State's definition of illegal military-style rifles unlawfully deprives Californians of owning weapons that are commonly allowed in most other states and by the U.S. Supreme Court."
https://patch.com/california/san-diego/u-s-judge-says-covid-vaccine-kills-more-ca-mass-shootings (Interesting read in general). A few more facts the article cites:
/"In California alone, 14 people have been killed in a mass shooting in 2021."
/"By comparison, there have been 232 mass shootings — typically defined as a shooting that injures or kills four or more — across the country in 2021, the New York Times reported."
/"California began restricting assault weapons in 1989 and has updated the law several times since. To date, there are an estimated 185,569 assault weapons registered within California, despite the ban, Benitez said." California is the state prone to exceptional levels of gun violence and mass shootings, in a count by statista
https://www.statista.com/statistics/811541/mass-shootings-in-the-us-by-state/
there are only ten U.S. states that have experienced 4 or more mass shooting event between 1982 and May 2021 (at least one per decade on average, definition is likely more strict):
California, Florida, Texas, Washington, Colorado, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Illinois, New York, Ohio (81 registered mass shooting events in total, or 8.1 per state in fourty years).
More than 25% of the events (22 in total) happened in California, or one mass shooting every other year, the most recent being a shooting in San Jose leavin nine dead.
While there is certainly a close correlation to population, population density, affordability of living, crime rates in general, ethnic conflicts (66 of the shooters were "White", 58 belonged to any other ethnicity, according to https://www.statista.com/statistics/476456/mass-shootings-in-the-us-by-shooter-s-race/ ), there is also a plain correlation to pervasiveness of firearms, which may be exceptionally high in California, and the population's tendency to own one. 
Most weapons used in mass shootings, about 80%, were obtained legally ( https://www.statista.com/statistics/476461/mass-shootings-in-the-us-by-legality-of-shooters-weapons/ )
While the highest new sales per capita is located in the Midwest and Northwest of the US
https://www.statista.com/chart/19718/estimated-gun-sales-per-1000-adults-in-us-states/
and California is somewhere in the middle when it comes to total gun ownership per capita
https://www.statista.com/chart/21894/firearms-in-each-state/ ,
the number of total firearms in circulation (must be near half a million) may be highest in California compared to the rest of the U.S. by its sheer population size.
On top of that, Los Angeles appears to have the highest number of all selected metropolitan areas in the U.S., and you are half as likely to bump into a gun shop as you are to bump into a Starbucks in LA.
https://www.statista.com/chart/5025/gun-shops-versus-starbuck-in-selected-us-cities/ To cut a long story short, it will be essential to know whether the CA court ruling about assault weapons takes effect immediately or whether it will be subject to revision or change or has a due date. However, the situation in California could outweigh the additional states in 2021 that have joined or will join the "Permitless carry" states, since after a low in mass shooting events in 2020, the numbers are on the rise again,
https://www.statista.com/chart/19376/number-of-mass-shootings/
the 2021 San Jose mass shooting could mean that Californians may increasingly consider a firearm purchase to be able to defend themselves, and most importantly, the recent court ruling now offers them the opportunity to legally purchase an assault weapon beyond a mere handgun in a short spree. Background checks may well total 3.3mn in June, but the total number Apr -Jun 2021 will be very close to 10mn. EDIT:
"The federal judge issued a permanent injunction against enforcement of the law but stayed it for 30 days to give state Attorney General Rob Bonta time to appeal."
https://patch.com/california/san-diego/federal-judge-overturns-cas-ban-assault-weapons

Average change May to June since 1999 is -1-2%, but that's elevated by spikes in 2020 (George Floyd protests) and 2016 (Orlando nightclub shooting). Besides those two cases it has averaged -3%, with a positive change in only 2 years out of 21. We'd need a 1.3% increase or larger to be above 10k, which occurred in 3 of 22 Junes (including 2016 and 2020).  Historic seasonality suggests another drop in June. That said, I thought the drop in May would be larger since we were at a higher point and were coming out of an election year and pandemic, but that doesn't seem to have been the case. May's drop was pretty much in line with historic numbers (-8.5%, vs -9.5% historically with SD of 6%). The uncertainty comes from the numbers being in a weird spot right now, and the risk of a mass shooting or other event in the next month scaring people into buying. We've had 11 major mass shootings in 5.5 years (2016-2021) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_shootings_in_the_United_States) including the recent San Jose rail yard shooting. There's no apparent preference for certain months so I assume the risk is equal over time, which puts the risk of one happening in June at about 17%. To cause a spike it'd have to happen sooner rather than later in the month and it's already the 6th, probably with at least 7 days left in the month, so that'd be a 10% chance of a mass shooting and subsequent increase. I'd bump that 2% for other possible events, for example like the George Floyd protests of last year, and add another 5% for uncertainty about applicability of historic trends to the currently very elevated numbers. The last main pieces of uncertainty come in around the hearings for David Chipman being appointed as the head of ATF and the spread of rhetoric about how he's going to take away everyone's guns, May purchases potentially being delayed to June by low inventories, lingering effects of the San Jose rail yard shooting, and an increase in the risk of a mass shooting as we reopen and large gatherings become more common. I don't have much confidence in my ability to price these in, all I know is that they're positive. Historically I've over-adjusted to new developments in my forecasts to my own detriment, so the total adjustment for all four of the previous factors combined is 7%, putting the 10-12M bucket at 24%.  Historically, background checks in June have increased by the requisite amount in 14% of months, so I am already betting on it at almost twice the base rate, but that still feels low. May was in line with historic rates too. This forecast is against my intuition but my past mistakes are pretty clear.

Readjusing based on a previous rationale of mine. In it, I noticed a cyclical trend and said to expect a general rise after June's data. Thus, I expect June to continue the downward trend, but I can't chase it because the overall trend is upward over the decades.

April = 3.514m
May = 3.222m Total = 6.736m
10m is an additional 3.264m, bang in the range, so 50/50 either side really.

Currently, roughly 6.836 M, so it'll take 3.264 to get to 10M.  There were 3.52M in April, down to 3.22M in May.  Usually, June is lower than May (3 out of the last 22 years, BUT twice in the last three).  This is going to be close.  Rising violence in the news weighs in favor of following the last two years' trend of a higher June.  Shortage of ammo and weapons.....I don't know how that cuts (why get a background check if you can't get a gun, but it heightens anxiety and maybe people will want to be ready in case their gun becomes available).  My best guess last time was 10.3M.  I think it's now 10.0M,  +/- 0.1M.  I'm going 51/49. [1] FBI data:  https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/nics_firearm_checks_-_month_year.pdf/view
FBI posted their May 2021 data. There's never been a single month big enough to push the quarterly count above 12MM, so revising that estimate to 0%.

It seems a number of states have already introduced or will introduce a law to allow their citizens a so called "constitutional" or permitless carry (the reason behind seemingly being massive more NRA lobbying success than a rational approach to a controversial matter in the context of the second amendment). The NRA has been in jeopardy due to their voluntary bankruptcy filing in the state of New York (which was declined in court) and their plans to move their domicile to Texas.
What is interesting now, is that TX Gov. Abbott has recently signed into law a bill that grants permitless carry to all Texans, as it seems, unless they have been blocked from a firearm purchase in a criminal background check before.
With Montana, Utah and Tennessee csmonitor lists three more states that have joined the state coalition of 22 states in 2021. Texas, being the most populous, is certainly the most influential.
https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2021/0602/Constitutional-carry-comes-to-Texas.-The-trend-in-five-charts
( https://www.galvnews.com/news/article_cb179454-2528-598c-9428-fd86cd113a1c.html (paywall))
This move could influence the outcome of this question in two ways:
/being aware of the law in the making, some future buyers will have waited for this moment and held out in order to avoid the procedure of an NICS for various reasons, most prominently, I assume, in order to avoid registration and to have a "private win" against the system and those liberal politicians who allegedly intend to take away from them their right to carry a firearm, following the narrative of a former president who believed the 2nd amendment to be "under siege".
/as a consequence, there could be some pent-up demand, but in sharp contrast to former months with jumps in firearm sales (June 2020, February 2021), this will likely NOT cause a higher number of NICS background checks, as these sales will now go ahead mostly unchecked, unless a check is being made voluntarily. Thus, I assume that between 5% and 10% of all new sales recorded in June 2021, which could come out at between 3.1mn and 3.4mn purchases (depending on the number of high scale events with large media coverage: criminal cases, assaults, mass shootings, terror attacks,...) under the April, May 2021 conditions, will now happen without leaving a trace of a NICS check at the FBI.
As a consequence, I have to revise down my forcast for June 2021 to 2.79mn to 3.23mn additional checks, which would almost certainly make the total of the months April through June 2021 fail to exceed 10.00mn NICS checks (they are required to exceed 3.263mn checks in June). Only in the extreme case, which would fuel much additional demand for firearms in all states but has little or no pent-up demand in the "permitless carry"-states, the third bin would still resolve this question.
Another thought of mine is, whether African Americans could have an incentive to increase the armament for self-defense (where eligible), now that the 100th anniversary of the 1921 Tulsa massacre is remembered and has some media coverage. It's really hard to say, until recently I clearly favored the third bin, but I also notice that in post-"Trump insurgency" times, the number of sales is likely to abate for some more month and normalize, since political order has been somewhat restored and uncertainty is kept at bay. Looting or fatal shootings happen, but at rates widely considered "normal" for the United States, and the reduction in checked sales could thus follow the same path as in June through September 2020, where advanced sales in the first month decimated new buyers in the following months.

April and May total of 6.734m makes passing 12m unlikely. A 34% or greater y/y growth happened 8 times in the last 12 months but only 6 times in the decade prior. The recent jumps can be strongly corelated to the pandemic and the threat to restrictions under the Biden administration. Prior to that there was a surge in the winter of 2015/16 following the San Bernadino shooting and increased talk of restrictions under the Obama administration. Pre-pandemic baseline would have been 5% and that momentum appears to be waning. That said, I'll still bump it up slightly to 7% with the caveat that an extreme event (large mass shooting) would significantly increase this probability. Conversely, with 3.266m needed to pass the 10m mark, a 17% drop in y/y checks would be very abnormal but still not impossible.  Every month has seen y/y growth since March of 2019, and June 2020 had 3.932m. A more significant drop hasn't happened since Dec 2016 and only three times in the last 20 years, giving it a baseline chance of less than a 2% it will fall below 3.266m. But, after reading @p00h about the May-June jump (or lack thereof) it seems this should be upped. I'm completely fudging this math (someone please correct me..) but 2% big picture, divided by 15% month to month, puts me at 13% (6ish times more likely may-june than between the normal month to month)... sure... I'll go with that...

Gun sales in the United States in May were the highest on record except for May 2020, according to an analysis of government data. Over 1.3 million background checks were conducted for the sale of a firearm,

3,264,000 or a 1.3% increase May to June needed to exceed 10,000,000. In the 20 year history so far, a month-over-month for May to June of this magnitude occurs less than 15% of the time. Median outcome is 9.9. Range is 9.6 to 10.8 with 95% confidence. Note to self:
Which is the better strategy? Ignore your last prediction and make a big move? Or acknowledge that your model is only one of many and split the difference?
Updating due to time and newly (ish) available data.

New numbers-
Nov 03, 2020 · With two months remaining in the year, the approximately 16.5 million background checks conducted between January and October 2020 for the sale or transfer of firearms and accessories eclipsed...
Estimated Reading Time: 4 mins
Author: Josh Campbell, CNN

God damn I cannot make up my mind, vol. 19. Stay tuned. Note to self: Average 0.066666666666667/1M increase each month for gun sales; peaks average every 10 months. With this data, maybe it ramps up again past June.

With 4 months of 2001 data
4 month average - 3.97
Jan - March average - 4.13
Feb - April average - 3.86 The strongest methodology would be to take the 
April actual - 3.5
Plus an average/forecast for the other two months. Low is 3.86, High is 4.13
Range therefore is 11.22 - 11.76. IF THINGS STAY STEADY STATE!  Could easily have a new outlier. 
However, I am going to put bulk on just under 12, with some 12-14.
@MCowley, seeing and running with an approx. +20% YoY delta.
No change today. @Jayce, what's your take on this one?

Registrations dropped in April. A further drop would hit the lower boundary and a return to earlier rates would hit the higher boundary in the 10-12 million band. It is looking less likely to hit 14 now. Lack of violence related to George Floyd killing kept numbers down.

The data from April shows 3.5M background checks for the month.  The numbers can be choppy, but this is a faster drop than I anticipated.  I still think the most likely result is 10M to 12M, but I now think it's more likely to be under 10M than over 12M as May and June now have to average about 4.25M which has never happened in two consecutive months.  My best guess is now 10.3M. [1]  https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/nics_firearm_checks_-_month_year.pdf/view
April numbers came in lower than I expected, just over 3.5 million.
They are a good investment and a great insurance policy.

3.5m in April means over 4.25 need each of the next 2 months needed to crack 12, which would be unusually high although not impossible. Seems a solid chance to crack 10 though as the monthly average over the last year is more than sufficient for that. Re-opening from covid could also provide a distraction and lower numbers.
I think applying the YoY growth rate to last year's May/June print is a better forecasting method (that accounts for seasonality) better than what I was doing before.
Or at least the should domore than 14 mil checks.

Dialing down to crowd forecast on 14m+ There is traditionally a dip in the 2nd quarter of the year for permits, although last year there was a spike. I still think permits will be up in 2021 compared to 2020, especially given the legislation around guns that has been talked about. But I'm less certain it will be a massive spike.
Not going in a good direction here

There is a bit of a rush among States Of A Certain Kind to adopt laws that render background checks unnecessary. Coming down a bit, not only because of those proposed statutes but also because a lot of People Of A Certain Kind assume the bills have already passed or will soon, and will skip the current requirements.   Meanwhile, between the increasing likelihood of getting on the wrong side of a massacre and the increasing likelihood of being caught in a crossfire, grownups throughout the US are compiling lists of states where it is no longer safe for them or their children to venture out of doors.  Grownups in other parts of the world are debating whether to come here at all.  Kinda makes you proud, huh?

April = 3.5m Thresholds
10m = 4.25m for each of next 2 months
12m = 3.25m for each of next 2 months Last time it was below 3.25m last Sept 20.  Never had 2 consecutive months over 4m, so very unlikely.
Thank you, @Foci for your data, analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1272776
April data is out and it seems my first forecasts are coming back to validity.

Trend is up recently but likely leveled off, and the historic seasonality strongly suggests a steady decline in April through July. Recent dips haven't been all that sharp after April, and the protests in June of last year on top of COVID make it difficult to determine whether declines will remain small this year or be magnified like the rest of the data seems to be. I think I gave too much credence to the recent huge spike in my prior forecast, though it was difficult to say where it would stop. Now that a lot of the distortion from the election should be subsiding, I'd expect a return to more normal historical trends. April is just above the monthly threshold for 10M, so it could easily fall on either side. As for mass shootings and gun control bills, its unclear what's going to happen, which makes the outcome barring a drastic change very hard to predict. We may see more mass shootings as we come out of a relative lull from COVID which would make the seasonal dip smaller or potentially make the rate rise, or the initial hype around gun control legislation under Biden may die down with nothing getting done, as unfortunately seems to be the pattern. It feels bad putting in a prediction like this, but the history is hard to ignore.
April numbers substantially off from March numbers, so reverting back towards my initial forecast.

April 2021 NICS statistics came in at 3.514MM checks, which I think makes numbers > 12MM unreachable (unless there is a backlash in response to new legislation). Was the largest volume ever recorded in April though.
https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/nics_firearm_checks_-_month_year.pdf/view
Running about 4 million a month so far this year, up a bit from last year but absent a big civil disturbance will most likely slow slightly to fall just below 12MM. Should be close.

4.3 M checks in Jan 2021 =>    4.3 M  * 3 = 12.9 M Checks in 2020:  39.7 M (https://gununiversity.com/gun-sales-stats/) =>    39.7 M  /  4 = 9.9 M Average of both would be 11.4 M. Give more weight to higher numbers since there seems to be an upward trend.

https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/17/attempts-at-tighter-gun-control-laws-will-make-headlines. The worst possible scenario for arms (given that the worst decline sales between 2 months in the past was 900 000) seems to be 3.8+2.9+2 (=8.8) which is higher than 8 million. If we just stay at the same level, we're higher than 12 000 000 and if we decline a bit we're between 10 and 12 million so these two outcomes are the most likely. The more than 14 000 000 would need the trend to still increase which isn't that unlikely but we'd need to go over 5 million on a single month at least once which isn't the most likely scenario.

March was 4.7MM, February was 3.4MM. As warmer weather begins in the US, I predict the violent crime rate will increase even more than it already has over the past year.  If gun control legislation passes, it will trigger even higher sales.

https://www.npr.org/2021/04/26/989699122/1st-time-gun-buyers-help-push-record-u-s-gun-sales-amid-string-of-mass-shootings
Increasing upper range to 5.6M / month -- lower range at 4.1M / month -- most likely 4.8M / month
I think with the new attempt at gun control we're going to see permits spike.

"We have only had over 4 million NICS checks in a month twice in history: both of them in 2021… January of this year and last month." (March). https://gununiversity.com/gun-sales-stats/
So, will April, May and June continue that high trend?  Jan, Feb, March give us 12.45MM.  But that includes two of the highest numbers ever.  So it could easily come in just under that.  I am going to give decent odds to 10-12 and 12-14, with possible outlier of more than 14.
pace will remain strong, but post election frenzy will ebb
The ammosexual madness accelerates with every shooting.
Adjusting up to 10-12/12-14m. Numbers from the last three months have been high

Just eye balling prior years, there is usually a decline in the number of firearms checks in Q2 each year, compared to Q1. It's true the last quarter showed record numbers of checks, so very possible that upward trend may continue, but I am sticking with historic trends in guessing we'll see a slight decline compared to Q1 2021, which was approx. 12.4 mm checks in total. 70% chance we the number dips below the 12 mm point, at around 11.5  mm or so, 30% chance the current upward trend continues, and we do another 12 mm upwards in numbers.
4.7m check in March.  Blooming ‘eck!  Will have to raise forecast for likelihood of getting over 12m...

Gun purchases are less than half the total. Federal Bureau of Investigation’s National Instant Criminal Background Check System saw 4,691,738 checks initiated in March 2021, the highest figure logged since NICS was established in 1998.

Our local pawn shop did $48,000 in business last month- the majority of which was gun sales according to the manager.  This is a rural area, so local citizens lean farther right than the current administration and many fear losing their gun ownership rights.

I'm revising my estimate upwards in light of March numbers and the President's recent policy announcement if March numbers held constant for the next quarter that would be 14,075,214
The data in past years always shows a drop off in April and then a slight rise over the second quarter.
However the trend since last Oct has been increasing every month which is unusual. typically there is some variation, so I think it is a strong enough trend to bet on it continuing. Mostly because this is such a contentious issue, gun sales always go up under democratic presidents and the country is even more deeply divided than under past democratic presidents. Gun enthusiasts are losing their minds over the President's new gun policy https://www.forbes.com/sites/petersuciu/2021/04/08/reactions-to-president-bidens-gun-control-actions-trending/?sh=3d84ddbc3304
keep in mind this is a forbes article, so it is a very tame summary of the negative reaction mostly from elected officials. the reaction in the gun buying public is vitriolic. The new policy will increase gun sales, the only question is by how much and will they be sales that require background checks, i.e. first time buyers through dealers?  There are limits to how high the background check number will go
-Lots of gun sale activity in the short term will be people buying ghost guns before the rule changes to require a background check. 
-Based on the increased prices for ammunition and guns it seems that demand is likely above supply which may limit the increase.  
- 4 million/month is high but I think sustainable over the next three months. There are about 200 million Americans old enough to buy a gun.  if we assume half want to buy a gun that is roughly two years of back ground check demand at 4 million/month .
Following my previous logic and the fact Biden is pushing for more gun laws, I can (assumption follows) expect more gun registration over the next several months.

Adjusting up with the March numbers and recent announcements likely to increase checks the total being under 10 seems far less likely and the bubble moving closer to the 12M, although still under as checks historically dip ~15% in Apr/May/June (prior to the last couple years that is...)

I forgot I had done some quantitative forecasting on this so updating again: I had forecast March would be around 4,131,332, after adjusting down 15% from my original forecast of 4,818,669. It was in fact in between those two at 4,691,738, although closer to my original forecast. That puts my new forecast at 13 million.
No change to forecast but I think Biden's EO today will cause a spike in first-time buyers that will show in the permit applications now that we're in April.

Data from https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/nics_firearm_checks_-_month_year.pdf/view shows a huge increase in 2021 (approx. 600k more per month in 2021 yoy Jan/Feb, and more than 900k yoy in March), and given Biden's gun control drive I expect that sales will continue to be pushed to capacity. Checks Jan-Mar topped 12.4 million, and I expect that to increase in line with both previous years and due to political moves toward gun control.

There were roughly 12.5M background checks Jan-Mar 2021.  There was a similar spike in 2008/9 after a Democrat was elected president (and/or financial crisis?), but started earlier (Nov).  If we used 2008/9 as a model, the jump was roughly 50% for two months, then stayed up about 30% for about 4 months.  In 2020/21, there was also a 50% (roughly) jump, but in January (preceded by more of a ramp-up too, so not the same shape already), which would imply something like 30% above the 3Mish level for Apr-Jun.  3.5 to 3.9 M per month for 3 months gives 10.5 - 11.7 total.  But, given coming out of a pandemic and economic slump rather than going deeper in, increased political polarization, and 12.5 for the prior three months, breaking 12M seems very plausible, if slightly less likely than the 11.6M which is my best guess. Not sure if this is the proper tool to use in this context, but I averaged 4 years to come up with a ratio of 7.45 JAN FEB MAR:7.175 APR MAY JUN. Since March 2021 is not out yet I just assumed an average between JAN and FEB and added it to the sum of JAN and FEB. That got me above 11M. Since the ratio gives a tendency to fall short in APR MAY JUN compared to JAN FEB MAR, I assume a greater probability for it to be less than 11M than greater. Additionally, it is behind in catching up to 2020's total at this time of year last year, even though the beginning of 2021 had a greater headstart than 2020.

Interestingly, I had a conversation with someone who is much more tuned into the gun world than I am, working in the industry. He noted that federal firearms background checks can be misleading RE: total demand, because they mostly capture new gun owners, not existing gun owners buying a second or third gun. Additionally, they don't capture CCW permit holders who are buying their first guns (because the CCW supercedes the federal background check), and they don't capture handgun purchases in several states. This doesn't change my forecast, but it is important information to keep in mind when looking at the impact of events on people's desire to own guns.

On average, NICS background checks increase by 8% year over year. For 2021, this would mean 42.9 million background checks. April through June averages 21.5% of the year, resulting in 9.2 million background checks for this period in 2021. 
If we assume that 2021 follows a similar trajectory as 2013, the only year with a similar annual increase in January, background checks would drop to half in June.  This would result in a similar forecast of 8 - 9 million. There were also more background checks in January and February 2013 than from April to June 2013.
Reasons that there could be more background checks are fear of more gun regulation under Biden [ https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/03/gun-sales-background-check-legislation-back-congress/6906980002/ ]  and a general compounding effect where everyone wants to get a gun because everyone else has one.

Looking at the data in the NICS chart for 1999-2020, Q1 averages 25% of the yearly total, Q2 averages 21% of the yearly. Zooming in on just the last 3 years, Q1 is still 25% while Q2 is about 25% as well, up from 21. This might reflect changes in seasonal patterns over the years, I'm not sure. Again, looking at Jan 2021 the numbers are significantly higher. From 2018-2020, January was about 30% of the quarter. February was 31, March was 40. Since we have January, I'm going to estimate that Feb 2021 is around 4,015,557 and Mar 2021 is around 4,818,669. If those numbers hold, we should expect to see around 13,152,031 background checks in Q2, but potentially as low as 11,047,705 (which is the 21% figure.) The reason I put 10-12m at 30% is that I'm not sure if gun demand will tail off as everyone who wants a gun goes out and gets one, or there are supply chain difficulties.
